material.mattext: Which of these describes good writing?
All these are valued skills in written communication except?
Critical thinking and analytical reasoning skills
The ability to locate, organise, and evaluate information from multiple sources
The ability to analyse and solve complex problems
The ability to gather information from multiple sources and copy them word for word
Which of these do you not do when trying to understand an assignment?
Recognize implied questions in the assignment
Start answering the question before brainstorming
Understand how the assignment should be answered
In order to write a well structured paragraph,
All these are methods used when brainstorming except?
These options form part of the stages of writing except?
What happens when you wait till the last minute to complete an assignment given?
These are things you can do when fear sets in in the process of writing except?
In free writing, there is a need to:
Not worry about your grammar or spellings
Come up with new ideas every minute
An advantage that comes with the writing process is that:
You have to finish a process thoroughly before moving to the next
You can go back to a previous step
It’s easy to get sidetracked and not make progress
One activity that helps when writing out an assignment or any piece of writing is to
Choose not to understand what is required
Ask questions that pave way for your writing
Procrastinate and leave work until the last minute
Write without considering your intended audience
How do you determine the purpose of an assignment?
Through the wording of the assignment
By focusing on elements you find interesting
These are things you need to establish before beginning the writing process except?
Identify the required style of the paper
Determine the purpose of the work
Make sure your subject is very broad
Writing can cause occasional anxiety for:
What can one do when overwhelmed with the vastness of an assignment?
Ask a mate to write for you
In brainstorming, it is important to consider the order in which your ideas are written.
What is the purpose of background research?
To fill in gaps in knowledge
The research process is strictly a linear process
Which of the following best describes the recommended process for narrowing a research topic?
Jump straight to formulating a thesis statement
Move from a broad subject to a more focused topic to a specific issue
Begin with background research then formulate questions
Start with secondary questions then determine primary sources
A working thesis statement does all the following except?
Narrows the subject to the single point that readers should understand
Names the topic and makes a significant assertion about that topic
Students are encouraged to make use of _____ more often for their research
Which of these options does not fall into the research process?
Why is it important to finish one step before the other in the research process?
It is not necessary to do so
How can you keep track of your research citations while working?
By storing them in a folder
By waiting till the end of your writing
What does the CRAP method stand for?
Currency, Reliability, Authority, Purpose/Point of view
Currency, Reliability, Availability, Purpose/point of view
When evaluating currency, which of the following would be most important?
Which criteria of the CRAP method involves detecting bias or loaded language?
Which criteria of the CRAAP test methods is most important when timeliness is crucial?
Which of the CRAAP test methods involves assessing spelling, grammar and errors?
Which of the CRAAP test methods discriminates between objective information from bias or emotion?
changing a lot of the vocabulary
The purpose of an introduction is:
to give your aims and methods
Copying a paragraph, but changing one or two and giving a citation can be
Reducing the length of a text but retaining the main points can be termed as:
Which of these is not a characteristic of an effective paraphrase?
has a different structure to the original
keeps some phrases from the original that are in common use
What are the three stages of effective reading?
What should be excluded from a summary?
Accurate representation of the original text
How should a well-organised summary be structured?
Making predictions about the probable meaning of a text is not an effective reading strategy?
